values: Welcome to Lizzie's LJ. Long-lost friends, please leave comments below. Almost all my posts are locked to friends only.
Tell me about your favourite Shakespeare sonnet.

Anyways, here are some of the results:

Hi everyone.  I haven't read anything on here for about two months and I feel a little disconnected.  Could you please tell me the most exciting and interesting and lifechanging things that have happend to each of you in the last coupla months? :)

As you can probably guess, school has just recently finished and I have some time again.

HAPPY BIRTHDAY FRAN!

Everyone say "Hurrah for the special birthday girl!" below:

Happy Birthday Madeleine! :)

If I wasn't a very undutiful elder sister who is shamefacedly too busy to say how fantastic her younger sister is on her 14th birthday, I would write a very long message here describing what a wonderful and talented person my dear little Maddy is :)

You all may leave well-wishing comments here:

May you all have a blessed and holy Easter season, and realise afresh the beauty of God's love for each one of you.  Don't forget, however awful life ever gets and however much suffering happens to you and around you, you can rejoice because at the end, you can be happy with Him in Heaven for all eternity, just because He loved us to death. Isn't that awesome (in the old-fashioned sense of the word)?

:)

Australia is so good that it's boring. And if England plays for a draw over the next two days, it's going to be super-boring. That century from Gilchrist wasn't at all boring though. I've decided that he's the hero of the XI at the moment, not because he hits amazing sixes, but because he's a Very Good Sport and a Fine Role Model. Um, are any of you watching the Ashes too? Please say that you are... By the bye, have any of you noticed how tiring holidays can be? :)\ And my brother looked over my should just then while I was typing. Something about this entry is making him snigger his head off. I'm almost too scared to post it now, but maybe he was just teasing about nothing?

Yay! I can finally watch the cricket. I was tooo busy for the last two games. I actually really hope England win this one, so that we have to have one more, therefore more cricket to watch. :) And quickly: Thank you for your suggestions, but both the post office and the newsagent I looked in were totally empty of notepaper. **sobs** I think I'll try K-Mart next. Isn't it shocking that I've never actually bought writing paper before? Thank you all sooo much for your lovely messages and wishes yesterday. I had the most happy birthday ever. :) EDIT: My brother informs me I can stop cheering for the Poms, because they play the last two matches in any case. *sigh* I'm so ignorant. :(
Whereabouts do you people buy nice writing paper?  I mean the sort you write letters to people with, that looks pretty.  What sort of shops do you browse in?

Guess what? You will not believe this. Well, three of you will: We just had an hourandahalf of chatting and coffee with the Gorgeous Waltz_Matilda & Family! Is that not exciting? And now we have to leave for somewhere, so I shall say au revoir. Au revoir.
Did reading Iain Serraillier's The Silver Sword change your life?

I <3 German music, especially the Comedian Harmonists. When they sing, they use their voices as musical instruments, and I like that.  The Mills Brothers do that too.  I <3 them as well.  They aren't German, BTW.

One of the things that greatly annoyed me when I switched computers at the beginning of the year is that when I transferred my music collection, the ratings I had so carefully chosen for each song didn't come too. *big bottom lip pout*  This means I can't just click on the "Play-all-5-star-songs-playlist".

And how does this count as a proper Journal entry?  Because it shows you just what is going on in my little corner of the world: I'm distracting myself from my assignments.

No, actually my assignments are coming along quite well, thank you.  I just wanted to ask you people a question:

<lj-poll-860028>

Thanks for your participation. If you registered your answer before Christmas 2005, you will automatically receive a free set of steak knives.
Did you know that eating burnt U2 t-shirts gives you cancer of the colon?  Fran told me this.  She knows.  She burns a lot of things and eats them.  Mainly toast.

Oh! Urgent update!! Somehow a most important sentence got left off my description of the first photo in my last post! It should read thus: ...to all the people who helped her through: Dad, Mum, Jean, Izz, Paul, Andy, Maddy, John, Bill. And Nice People in Armidale like Fran and Elizabeth H. And, of course, the Wonderful People on LJ who listened to her whinging about it at the end of last year and had funny cheery conversations with her to make her happeee. This refers, of course, to ,, and last but not least , all of which probably don't realise how inspiring and cheering their delightful comments and posts were. :)

I haven't been here in yonks, it feels.   And why am I back?  I overheard a piece of wisdom this evening, and it was so "wow!", although I already knew it, and I wanted to share it, but no one was around... so I thought of my ready made audience here! :P

<i>"Life is not as complex as some people think.  You do what is right, and God looks after you."

It's nice to hear things like that, especially from the people closest to you.  There was more, but it doesn't fit...

Hope you are all well, and may God bless you and be with you in your sufferings and joys this week...

For those of you who have my email and have sent/are sending me email in the last/next little while, please note that my old email address no longer exists, I have a new one and I will be sending an email out to everyone on my address list in the near future.  In the meantime, that address no longer exists.
Trespaddressing: noun, to comment in another person's journal in order to have a conversation with a third person.
argh.  that is looong.  I'm going out the door but I'll put it under a cut when I return, ok?

A warning:  It is all in Latin.

Just a bit less than a year ago, I had the great fortune to meet, only for a few minutes, a personage by the name of Danielle. Since she was the cousin of my friends, I had actually popped across and read her LiveJournal several times before this. It was so interesting and inspiring and unwhingy that I really wanted to friend her. Of course, I was too shy to leave a comment on the LJ of someone I didn't know in real life! But naturally, in the few minutes that we chatted, we agreed to friend each other. And so we did, and reading Danielle's LiveJournal has been a reg'lar habit of mine ever since. And, you know, I am very, very thankful to have such a Wise And Entertaining Person on my friends list. Because, you see, she wears many hats. She's a Philosopher, Poet, Good-Example-Setter, Author of Sketches Both Graphic and Verbal, Leaver Of Comments Cheeky Or Encouraging As Appropriate, Photographer, and of course, Proclaimer of God's Love. I've typed this out because I think people often don't get a chance to know what Important Friends they are. And I'm really proud to count Danielle as an Important Friend, even though we have actually only known each other for a very short time. What better time to tell her than on her birthday? So Big Enormous Birthday Greetings and Blessings to , and I hope that every one of her dreams, both big and little, will be fulfilled in the Lord's special way in the coming year. Thank you, Danielle, and Happy 26th Birthday!

The only problem with having your email account constantly online and checking, is that you become very aware of all the seconds every day during which you are not receiving emails. *gentle sob* I dreamed last night that I was playing the bazouki I tried out in Athens. The beautiful tinkly harpsichord sound was so real. I don't usually hear sounds in my dreams very clearly... Do you hear sounds in your dreams? Which of your senses is most clear in your dreams? Back to writing tests... I've just discovered that the section of text I was going to copy off the Internet isn't there, so I have to type it all in by hand. Bother. A very happy and blessed Sunday to you all! :D

I was doing some soul-searching today... and the topic of my soul-searching was: why don't I post on LJ anymore? I didn't really find an answer [apart from the fact that a) I have nothing to say and b) I have no time in which to say this nothing] but the result has been that I have sat down to post several times. I have just finished bagging meat for Mum. She has a very clever system in which the different types of meat are divided into meal sized bags and given labels with the date and type of meat before going in the freezer... because, as everyone knows, it is very hard to work out whether that lump of ice will emerge as a steak or a sausage when it is defrosted. Waltz_matilda, I'm very sorry we didn't make it to the concert tonight ;( Next time! Let us know when the next one is... Well, that's about it I guess. I feel like I should repeat my deepest apologies for two things: 1. lack of commenting. I HAVE read all our posts, but I'm flat out working and living so I have commented not wisely or too well. 2. trip stuff. photos coming, I promise. also day-by-day accounts (after we've finished going through the day-by-day accounts with the rest of our family here!!) I would tell you a little anecdote or two right now, but the only one I can remember is about the Greek toilets, and you don't want to hear that, do you? Good night all!

An absolutely fantastic quote came in on my daily RSS internet feed from quotation.com the other day: "I've got a vendetta to destroy the Net, to make everyone go to the library. I love the organic thing of pen and paper, ink on canvas. I love going down to the library, the feel and smell of books." -Joseph Fiennes Wow, how wonderful, thought I. It's so true! This internet is soaking up my brain, and destroying the real pleasures of life, and reading, and research. I wonder who this Joseph Fiennes is anyway? So I loaded up Google and typed him in, and found out all about him and what he looks like and other interesting things he has had to say. And then I made a resolution that I would put his vendetta into practice. This useless internet would nevermore hold me in thrall! I was never going to use it again. The real, tactile, crinkly page world was where I belonged, and whence I would now return. And then I thought about how, without the internet and feed readers and Google, I would never have realised that I should get rid of my internet and feed readers and Google. This puzzled me a bit, so i need to ask you a question. Which of the following is true? 1. The internet is self-destructing by allowing quotations such as this to float around in the ether. 2. The quotation is self-destructing because it isn't published in a book or library - you can only find it by floating around the internet-ether. And totally irrelevantly: the word 'quote' gives me the horrors. It would creep into my thesis last year, continuously, driving my pore supervisor crazy because he thought it was my fault that I couldn't say 'quotation'. And now I picture the word 'quote' as a silly little teenage girl talking to fast about a thesis that is too simple and unsophisticated for words, and I see 'quotation' as a tall, old man, balding with grey hair. ;)

Hi peoples! First of all, my deepest, deepest apologies for keeping you in suspense re photos and stories from The Trip. :( Here is a little taste for you. Isn't it gorgeously beautiful scenery? We thought so. I believe if you click on the photos you get a clearer view. Here is the bay of Naples. We were driving around from Sorrento to Pompeii. Here is the photo with handy marks explaining certain pixels. The big red circle is our boat, the Seabourn Spirit. Our cabin marked with an X. The little circle is the tender which drove us into the wharf and back. Middle right arrow points off to the Isle of Capri. Left double arrow points to yukky rocky beach. Lower right arrow with curly tail points to Pompeii and Mt Vesuvius. The next item is something which I would prefer not to post. I am posting it under suffrance. It was filmed to entertain my dear little brothers and sisters, who like that song. It's a song about the port we are at. The song is called Torna Sorrento - Return to Sorrento. I feel like the white knight in Alice through the Lookingglass. It's 2MB, so I 'spect you won't be able to look at it... Oh yay it's not uploading... I'll come back and have another go sometime else... We'll try and get some photos with-people-and-fascinating-places-in-them uploaded ASAP. :D Ooh, and maybe, just maybe, we might be able to go to a concert on Saturday evening. Maybe. I hope. Waltz-matilda, do you know which concert? :D Yes, that one!

And BTW, we actually managed to fulfil all the photo requests (except I think one of dizzyliz's) at great risk to our health and wellbeing.  If I'd known that we would be driven out of the Parthenon hunted by guards blowing whistles, I would never have promised to take on Danielle's dare :P  But we got the photo! :D

That's an exaggeration, btw.

Home again, home again, jiggety jig.

:D
A happy and blessed birthday to you, oh lonely wandering maiden.  May you have many more like this, and even better!

Just quickly:  leave a comment requesting your personal photo-souvenir for us to take while we are overseas.  Of what shall it be, and in what pose shall we be?

I'm sick. 

Last night before I woke up sick I dreamed I was walking around in the concept map I made for my assignment.  It was quite an Alice in Wonderland moment. And then I found fifty dollars.

My assignment is finished. You didn't even know I'd started it, did you, because I haven't posted in years!

I had to stay home in bed today.

Life is pretty busy at the moment. I thank the Lord that I do not have any exams this semester.

dizzy_liz is sweet. You all are, actually, but dizzy_liz cheered my moping hours of agony today. :)

The words of wisdom that pop into my email inbox every morning from Daily Gospel are priceless. And it is nice to know that Catholics 2000 years ago believed exactly what I believe today, right down to minute details.

This is an exciting and enlightening post, no? Ask me a question so that I have something to talk about. Any question. A random question.

Teaching is good, but stressful. I've learned so much. It gives me lots of food for thought, the chief thought being that I will definitely homeschool any children God gives me, DV.

Reader Participation: Would you like to travel to Europe? How much? Why? Where?

:( I'm feeling ill again. Adieu 

PS How could I forget?  Australia scored their first goal in a World Cup ever.  I really think they are most likely to win now. :P  I'm not serious.  It will be England or Germany who wins.  I hope England, but I think Germany.

... Hooray!!

*teeth chatter*

... but they are really specially good! This one isn't a commentary, just a quotation. Holy Gospel of Jesus Christ according to Saint John 6,52-59. The Jews quarreled among themselves, saying, "How can this man give us (his) flesh to eat?" Jesus said to them, "Amen, amen, I say to you, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood, you do not have life within you. Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise him on the last day. For my flesh is true food, and my blood is true drink. Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood remains in me and I in him. Just as the living Father sent me and I have life because of the Father, so also the one who feeds on me will have life because of me. This is the bread that came down from heaven. Unlike your ancestors who ate and still died, whoever eats this bread will live forever."
Thanks for the hug, kind person!
